slideInfo.title: Analyzing Political Cartoons
slideInfo.info: “Property Protected, a la Francoise” by Anonymous, Published in London, June 1, 1798

pButton.Name: Caricature
pButton.popInfo: Caricature exaggerates features of a person or thing. The exaggerated features say something about the subject’s appearance, character, beliefs, actions, or significance.

pButton.Name: Symbolism
pButton.popInfo: A symbol is an object that stands for something else. In political cartoons, a symbol is a recognizable object that represents something abstract or invisible, such as a dove representing world peace.

pButton.Name: Irony
pButton.popInfo: Irony is the use of words or actions that contradict what is really going on.

pButton.Name: Metaphor
pButton.popInfo: A metaphor relates two completely different objects to each other.

pButton.Name: Stereotype
pButton.popInfo: Stereotypes take a real or an imagined trait of one individual and make it true for the whole group to which the individual belongs. They are usually dangerous because they often lead to prejudice and can dehumanize individuals.
